H0.text: Deciduous trees are the type of tree dominant in temperate forests.

H1.text: Vines are the type of tree that is dominant in temperate forests.

H2.text: Fungus is the type of tree that is dominant in temperate forests.

H3.text: Shrubs are the type of tree that is dominant in temperate forests.

A4.text: Temperate deciduous forest biomes are plant communities distributed in North and South America, Asia, Southern slopes of the Himalayas, Europe and for cultivation purposes in Oceania.

A5.text: The Southern United States also has poor fall colors due to warm temperatures during the fall months and the Western United States as it has more evergreen and fewer deciduous plants, combined with the West Coast and its maritime climate.

A6.text: Deciduous forests are composed mainly of broadleaf trees, such as maple and oak, that shed all their leaves during one season.

A7.text: Coniferous forests are composed of needle-leaved evergreen trees, such as pine or fir.

A8.text: In some, needleleaf trees dominate, while others are home primarily to broadleaf evergreen trees or a mix of both tree types.

A9.text: However, some forests may support a layer of shrubs.

A10.text: Temperate coniferous forests are a type of temperate forest.

A11.text: Media related to temperate coniferous forests exist on Wikimedia Commons.

A12.text: In the Northern Hemisphere, pines Pinus, spruces Picea, larches Larix, firs Abies, Douglas firs Pseudotsuga, and hemlocks Tsuga make up the canopy; but other taxa are also important.

A13.text: Where rainfall is relatively evenly spread across the seasons in temperate regions, temperate broadleaf and mixed forest typified by species like oak, beech, birch and maple is found.

A14.text: In cool temperate regions, conifers often predominate; a widely distributed climax community in the far north of the northern hemisphere is moist taiga or northern coniferous forest (also called boreal forest).
